title: How to Make Light Fettuccine Alfredo

methods.name: Making Light Fettuccine Alfredo Using Yogurt

steps.headline: Cook the fettuccine.
steps.description: Bring a large sauce pot full of water to a boil over high heat. Once the water boils, remove the lid and add 1 pound (454 g) of dry fettuccine pasta. Boil the fettuccine according to the manufacturer's instructions and stir it occasionally to prevent it from sticking together. Drain the pasta once it's finished cooking. You can make the sauce while the pasta is boiling.

steps.headline: Saute the garlic and add the wine.
steps.description: Get out a saucepan and put 2 tablespoons of unsalted butter in it. Turn the heat on to medium-low, so the butter melts. Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and saute it for 1 minute. Stir in 1/2 cup (120 ml) of white wine and turn up the heat so the liquid starts to simmer. Remove it from the heat. You can substitute water or broth for the white wine. If you use chicken or vegetable broth, the sauce may not be very white.

steps.headline: Whisk in the yogurt, cheese, and seasoning.
steps.description: Let the garlic wine sauce cool for a few minutes and then whisk in 1 cup (285 g) of plain Greek yogurt, 1 cup (100 g) of shredded Parmesan cheese, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of coarse black pepper. Heat the sauce over low heat for 3 to 4 minutes while you stir constantly. Heating the sauce over low heat will help the cheese dissolve into the sauce. Just ensure that the sauce doesn't simmer or boil because it could curdle and separate.

steps.headline: Combine the light alfredo sauce with the pasta.
steps.description: Add the cooked and drained fettuccine pasta to the pan with the alfredo sauce. Use tongs or a few spoons to stir the noodles into the sauce, so they're completely coated. Divide the light fettuccine alfredo into four dishes and serve the pasta while it's still warm. If your saucepan isn't large enough to hold the sauce and the noodles, transfer the sauce and noodles to the large saucepot to combine them.

methods.name: Making Light Fettuccine Alfredo Using Milk and Neufchatel Cheese

steps.headline: Cook the fettuccine.
steps.description: Bring a large sauce pot full of water to a boil over high heat. Once the water boils, remove the lid and add 8 ounces (226 g) of dry fettuccine pasta. Boil the fettuccine according to the manufacturer's instructions and stir it occasionally to prevent it from sticking together. Drain the pasta once it's finished cooking. You can make the sauce while the pasta is boiling.

steps.headline: Saute the garlic and add the flour.
steps.description: Place 1 tablespoon of butter in a medium saucepan and turn the heat on to medium. Add 2 minced garlic cloves to the melted butter and saute the garlic for 1 minute. Stir in 1 tablespoon of flour. The mixture should turn into a thin paste. This roux (cooked butter and flour) will help the sauce thicken.

steps.headline: Whisk in the milk and cook the sauce.
steps.description: Slowly pour in 1 1/3 cups (320 ml) of low-fat milk with one hand while you use the other hand to whisk constantly. Keep whisking and cooking the alfredo sauce for about 6 minutes. It should start to thicken up. Try to use 1% low-fat milk for the best flavor. You can also use skim milk, but the sauce may not thicken as much.

steps.headline: Whisk in the cheeses and salt.
steps.description: Measure out 1 cup (100 g) of the shredded Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and whisk it into the sauce along with 2 tablespoons of neufchatel cheese and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Keep whisking the sauce until both the cheeses dissolve. Neufchatel cheese is also labeled as 1/3-less-fat cream cheese since it's a lower fat option than cream cheese.

steps.headline: Combine the fettuccine with the sauce.
steps.description: Add the cooked and drained pasta into the saucepan with the alfredo sauce. Use kitchen tongs or two spoons to mix the pasta with the sauce. Sprinkle the reserved 1/4 cup (25 g) of Parmigiano-Reggiano over the pasta. You can garnish the pasta with 2 teaspoons of chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley and a little fresh cracked black pepper.

methods.name: Making Light Fettuccine Alfredo Using Cauliflower

steps.headline: Cook the fettuccine.
steps.description: Bring a large sauce pot full of water to a boil over high heat. Once the water boils, remove the lid and add 1 pound (454 g) of dry fettuccine pasta. Boil the fettuccine according to the manufacturer's instructions and stir it occasionally to prevent it from sticking together. Measure out 1 cup (240 ml) of the starchy pasta water and set it aside. Drain the pasta once it's finished cooking. You can make the sauce while the pasta is boiling.

steps.headline: Chop and boil the cauliflower.
steps.description: Wash 3 small heads of cauliflower and discard any leaves. Use a sharp knife to carefully chop the cauliflower into chunks. Heat 6 cups (1.4 liters) of vegetable broth over medium-high heat until it boils and add the chopped cauliflower. Boil the cauliflower for about 15 minutes. It should become soft. If the cauliflower isn't completely tender when you remove it from the heat, the sauce may have more texture.

steps.headline: Saute the garlic.
steps.description: Melt 1 tablespoon of butter over medium heat in a large saucepan. Stir in 6 cloves of minced garlic and saute the garlic for 4 to 5 minutes. The garlic should smell aromatic when it's finished cooking. Keep an eye on the minced garlic since it can burn easily. If it looks like it's turning dark, turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Puree the soft cauliflower and aromatics.
steps.description: Scoop the cooked cauliflower into a blender or large food processor. Measure out 2 cups (473 ml) of the hot vegetable broth and add it to the blender. Add the sauteed garlic along with 1 teaspoon of salt, 1 pinch of nutmeg, and 1 pinch of black pepper. Puree the mixture for 5 minutes, so it becomes completely smooth. If you have a small blender or food processor, you can puree the cauliflower and aromatics in batches.

steps.headline: Blend in the olive oil.
steps.description: Open the pouring spout on the lid of your blender, so you can gradually pour in 1 tablespoon of olive oil while the sauce mixture is blending. If the sauce looks too thick, pour in a little extra vegetable broth. Pour the sauce back into the saucepan. If you don't want to add more vegetable broth, consider using plain water to thin the sauce.

steps.headline: Stir in cream and combine the pasta.
steps.description: Pour ¼ cup (60 ml) of heavy cream and 1 cup (240 ml) of the reserved starchy boiling water (from the pasta pot) into the sauce. Cook the sauce over low heat until it's slightly thick. Toss it together with the cooked and drained fettuccine. The starchy pasta water will thicken the cauliflower alfredo sauce.
